\section{Examples of Toda brackets}

Let \( R = \Fb_2C_2 \), with \( g \in C_2 \) being the generator.

Then \( J = \tuple{1 + g} \) is the only ideal of \( R \). And \( \frac{R}{J} \simeq J \).

First note that \( J \) is not projective, since the short exact sequence:

% https://q.uiver.app/#q=WzAsMyxbMCwwLCJKIl0sWzEsMCwiUiJdLFsyLDAsIkoiXSxbMCwxLCJcXGlvdGEiLDAseyJzdHlsZSI6eyJ0YWlsIjp7Im5hbWUiOiJob29rIiwic2lkZSI6InRvcCJ9fX1dLFsxLDIsIlxccGhpIiwwLHsic3R5bGUiOnsiaGVhZCI6eyJuYW1lIjoiZXBpIn19fV1d
\[\begin{tikzcd}
	J & R & J
	\arrow["\iota", hook, from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow["\phi", two heads, from=1-2, to=1-3]
\end{tikzcd}\]

Where, \( \iota \) is the inclusion, and \( \phi \) is the map:

\begin{align*}
    \phi: R &\to J \\
    0, 1 + g &\mapsto 0 \\
    1, g &\mapsto 1 + g
\end{align*}

Does not split, since \( \iota \) is the only monomorphism of \( J \) into \( R \), but composes to \( 0 \) with \( \phi \).

\subsection{Example 1}

The first example I calculated was the Toda bracket of the following diagram:
% https://q.uiver.app/#q=WzAsNCxbMCwwLCJKIl0sWzEsMCwiSiJdLFsyLDAsIkoiXSxbMywwLCJKIl0sWzAsMSwiXFxJZCJdLFsxLDIsIjAiXSxbMiwzLCJcXElkIl1d
\[\begin{tikzcd}
	J & J & J & J
	\arrow["\Id", from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow["0", from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow["\Id", from=1-3, to=1-4]
\end{tikzcd}\]

Using the cofiber-cofiber definition, one gets the following diagram:

% https://q.uiver.app/#
\[\begin{tikzcd}
	J & J & R & {\frac{R}{J}} \\
	J & J & J & J
	\arrow["\Id", from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["0", from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["\Id", from=2-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow[Rightarrow, no head, from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow[Rightarrow, no head, from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow["\Id", from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow[from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow[from=1-3, to=1-4]
	\arrow["\phi"', from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow["\psi", from=1-4, to=2-4]
\end{tikzcd}\]

However, since it's in \( \StMod(R) \), one has that \( R = 0 \), and \( \phi = 0 \). And since \( \frac{R}{J} \simeq J \), one gets the following diagram in \( \StMod(R) \):

% https://q.uiver.app/#
\[\begin{tikzcd}
	J & J & 0 & J \\
	J & J & J & J
	\arrow["\Id", from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["0", from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["\Id", from=2-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow[Rightarrow, no head, from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow[Rightarrow, no head, from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow["\Id", from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow["0", from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow["0", from=1-3, to=1-4]
	\arrow["0"', from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow["\psi", from=1-4, to=2-4]
\end{tikzcd}\]

But this shows that any endomorphism on \( J \) makes the rightmost square commute, and is therefore in the Toda bracket (Up to composition by an isomorphism) of \( \toda{\Id_J, 0, \Id_J} \). But (I think, TODO) we only care about Toda brackets up to pre/post-composition of isomorphisms. Therefore \( \toda{\Id_J, 0, \Id_J} = \Hom_R(J, J) \).

\subsection{Example 2}

One has that \( \toda{\Id_J, \Id_J, \Id_J} = \emptyset \), since there is no distinguished triangle one can put in the cofiber-cofiber definition such that the squares commute. The cone of the identity map is always \( 0 \):

% https://q.uiver.app/#
\[\begin{tikzcd}
	J & J & 0 & J \\
	J & J & J & J
	\arrow["\Id", from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["\Id", from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["\Id", from=2-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow[Rightarrow, no head, from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow[Rightarrow, no head, from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow["\Id", from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow["0", from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow["0", from=1-3, to=1-4]
	\arrow["\psi", from=1-4, to=2-4]
	\arrow["0"', squiggly, from=1-3, to=2-3]
\end{tikzcd}\]

There is no squiggly map in the diagram above that can make the middle square commute.

Therefore \( \toda{\Id_J, \Id_J, \Id_J} = \emptyset \). And one has that (TODO: Cite, Supervisors said so) in general, for the Toda bracket \( \toda{f_3, f_2, f_1} \), if \( f_3 \circ f_2 \neq 0 \) or \( f_2 \circ f_1 \neq 0 \), then the Toda bracket will be empty. 

\subsection{Example 3}

In general, one has that for any triangulated category that if \( \toda{f_3, 0, \Id} \) is a well defined Toda bracket, then it is equal to \( \Hom(\Sigma(X_1), X_3) \). This is because the cone is \( 0 \):
% https://q.uiver.app/#
\[\begin{tikzcd}
	{X_1} & {X_1} & 0 & {\Sigma(X_1)} \\
	{X_1} & {X_1} & {X_2} & {X_3}
	\arrow["\Id", from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow["\Id", from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow[Rightarrow, no head, from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow[Rightarrow, no head, from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow[from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow[from=1-3, to=1-4]
	\arrow["0", from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{f_3}", from=2-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow["\psi", from=1-4, to=2-4]
	\arrow[from=1-3, to=2-3]
\end{tikzcd}\]

So any possible \( \psi \) will make the right square commute.

\subsection{Example 4}

Want to find the Toda bracket of the following maps:

% https://q.uiver.app/#q=WzAsNCxbMCwwLCJKIl0sWzEsMCwiSiBcXG9wbHVzIEoiXSxbMiwwLCJKIFxcb3BsdXMgSiJdLFszLDAsIkoiXSxbMCwxLCJcXGJlZ2lue3BtYXRyaXh9IDEgXFxcXCAxIFxcZW5ke3BtYXRyaXh9Il0sWzEsMiwiXFxiZWdpbntwbWF0cml4fSAxICYgMSBcXFxcIDEgJiAxIFxcZW5ke3BtYXRyaXh9Il0sWzIsMywiXFxiZWdpbntwbWF0cml4fSAxICYgMSBcXGVuZHtwbWF0cml4fSJdXQ==
\[\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&]
	J \& {J \oplus J} \& {J \oplus J} \& J
	\arrow["{\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}}", from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow["{\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 \end{pmatrix}}", from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow["{\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 \end{pmatrix}}", from=1-3, to=1-4]
\end{tikzcd}\]

Using the cofiber-cofiber definition, one gets the following commutative diagram:

% https://q.uiver.app/#
\[\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&]
	J \& {J \oplus J} \& J \& J \\
	\\
	J \& {J \oplus J} \& {J \oplus J} \& J
	\arrow["{\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}}", from=3-1, to=3-2]
	\arrow["{\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 \end{pmatrix}}", from=3-2, to=3-3]
	\arrow["{\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 \end{pmatrix}}", from=3-3, to=3-4]
	\arrow[Rightarrow, no head, from=1-1, to=3-1]
	\arrow["{\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}}", from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow[Rightarrow, no head, from=1-2, to=3-2]
	\arrow["{\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 \end{pmatrix}}", from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow["0", from=1-3, to=1-4]
	\arrow["{\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}}", from=1-3, to=3-3]
	\arrow["\psi", from=1-4, to=3-4]
\end{tikzcd}\]

Where the top row is distinguished.

Here one can see that the only possible map for the middle-right map is to be \( \left(
    \begin{smallmatrix}
        1 \\ 1
    \end{smallmatrix} \right)
    \) in order for the middle square to commute since \( \left(
    \begin{smallmatrix}
        1 & 1
    \end{smallmatrix} \right)
    \) is an epimorphism. Therefore one gets that \( \psi \) can be any endomorphism on \( J \), since the right square always composes to \( 0 \) either way.
